newsitem.title: USA: US stocks end up, unfazed by capital gains plan.
newsitem.headline: US stocks end up, unfazed by capital gains plan.

text.p: U.S. stocks ended higher on Thursday, lifted after a drop in long-term interest rates that helped investors put a positive spin on the impact of a proposed capital gains tax cut, traders and analysts said.
Trading went against conventional wisdom that news of a proposal to make a capital gains tax cut effective as of Wednesday would unleash a wave of pent-up selling on Thursday.
The Dow finished up 51 points at 7137, backing off in late trade from a peak of 7215.
"It was definitely a shock," said Jay Meagrow, an institutional trader at McDonald & Co, referring to the market's reaction on Thursday. "I didn't see it coming."
The Nasdaq composite rose eight points to 1331.

After the stock market close on Wednesday, the Republican chairmen of the congressional tax-writing committees said they would propose setting May 7, 1997, as the effective date for a capital gains tax cut.
The tax cut would allow investors to keep more of their profits after they sell stocks and other securities.
Still, lightening the capital gains tax burden also makes investing in stocks more attractive, a view that apparently prevailed on Thursday, analysts said.
"The demand for stocks seems to be the dominant factor," said Robert Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First. "A rather positive spin is being given to this capital gains tax apparent agreement."
The Dow recovered from a 140-point decline on Wednesday, which was fueled by a rise in long-term interest rates in the bond market, analysts said.

But on Thursday, the yield on the closely watched 30-year Treasury bond backed away from 7.0 percent, a psychological barrier, setting the positive tone for stocks, market players said. The long bond was up 11/32 in late trading, its yield dropping to 6.94 percent from Wednesday's close at 6.96 percent.
"It adds a lot of octane to the equity market when rates move well below the seven percent," said Guy Truicko, equity portfolio manager at Unity Management.

Shares of International Business Machines Corp jumped 5-5/8 to 167-3/4 after company officials held an upbeat meeting with analysts late Wednesday. CS First Boston raised its 12-month price target on the stock to $195 from $165.
US Airways Group Inc rose 2-3/4 to 34-1/2 after the company said it would cut unprofitable routes and close some facilities in a sweeping restructuring aimed at cutting costs.
Energy stocks gained amid a rise in crude oil prices. Atlantic Richfield Co advanced 2-5/8 to 145-3/4, Texaco Inc gained 4-3/8 to 110-5/8 and Chevron Corp added one to 70-5/8.

United HealthCare Corp ended up 5/8 to 51-1/8 after hitting a session high of 53-1/2. The health maintenance organization reported a decline in first-quarter earnings but said new enrollment was strong and its retention rate was high in the face of price increases of more than five percent.

PETsMART Inc which runs a chain of pet supply superstores, fell 13/16 to 10-13/16. It said it expected its income from operations for its first quarter ended May 4 to fall short of Wall Street expectations.
